answer_html: Keep in mind that the code b=3:4:11; gives us the second row that begins at 3, increments entries by 4 and then goes up to 11.
answer_latex:
Keep in mind that the code b=3:4:11; gives us the second row that begins
at 3, increments entries by 4 and then goes up to 11.
hints_html:
Remember that a = x:y:z in MATLAB means create a vector a with first entry x, step size of y for entries across and stop when you exceed z. So for example, the first line produces

\(\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 5 \end{bmatrix}\)

The line A = [a;b] tells the computer to make a matrix with a on top then b underneath.
hints_latex:
Remember that a = x:y:z in MATLAB means create a vector a with first
entry x, step size of y for entries across and stop when you exceed z.
So for example, the first line produces

$\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 3 & 5
\end{bmatrix}$

The line A = {[}a;b{]} tells the computer to make a matrix with \emph{a}
on top then \emph{b} underneath.
hints_raw:
Remember that a = x:y:z in MATLAB means create a vector a with first entry x, step size of y for entries across and stop when you exceed z. So for example, the first line produces

<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 3 & 5
\end{bmatrix}
</math>
The line A = [a;b] tells the computer to make a matrix with ''a'' on top then ''b'' underneath.
question: A 29
sols_html:
Following the hints, we can quickly see that

\(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 5\\ 3 & 7 & 11 \end{bmatrix}\)

Keep in mind that the code b=3:4:11; gives us the second row that begins at 3, increments entries by 4 and then goes up to 11.
sols_latex:
Following the hints, we can quickly see that

$A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 3 & 5\\
3 & 7 & 11
\end{bmatrix}$

Keep in mind that the code b=3:4:11; gives us the second row that begins
at 3, increments entries by 4 and then goes up to 11.
sols_raw:
Following the hints, we can quickly see that

<math>
A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 3 & 5\\
3 & 7 & 11
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

Keep in mind that the code b=3:4:11; gives us the second row that begins at 3, increments entries by 4 and then goes up to 11.
statement_html:
Suppose we run the following MATLAB code.

a=1:2:5;
b=3:4:11;
A=[a;b];

Specify the matrix A that is produced by this code.
